Narrative:
Anais Nin – Risk

And then the day came,
when the risk
to remain tight
in a bud
was more painful
than the risk
it took
to blossom.

When was the day you stopped fulfilling and started leading your own life? For me, it came right after high school. Seeking the permission of others whilst forfeiting my own identity? Yeah, that wasn’t going to cut it anymore. It was time to take the plunge, aka, “blossom”, and remove any remnants of external expectations. As cliché as it sounds, it’s a crucial life lesson that comes with time, and few have interpreted this realisation as powerfully as Nin.

Little information is given about what led to this change, and there is also no evidence as to whether or not this change proved a good thing. By cutting off the poem at these beginning and ending points, Nin has made this ruling to change the focal point or the thing of importance within the poem. That change, as a theme for the poem, is treated like something to strive toward. Seemingly to the author, when we must push against conflicts, we should always aspire to grow to be our best versions.
Title: Risk by Anais Nin
